title: 114_hr2468
content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" encourages the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials. Grants will be awarded to expand opportunities for scientists and researchers, as well as promote the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in the health professions. Support for institutions in underrepresented communities for workforce development. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities that focus on health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving institutions, tribal colleges, and institutions with programs for minority health professionals. Islander-serving institutions, health professional associations, and institutions in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations can apply for grants from the Secretary of Health and Human Services to increase workforce diversity. The application must meet specific requirements set by the Secretary. The Secretary of Health and Human Services offers grants for workforce diversity programs in health professions. Applicants must submit an application with required information. Funds can be used for expanding, implementing, or evaluating diversity programs, including mental health care professions. Activities may include educational outreach, scholarships, postbaccalaureate programs, mentoring, and internship programs. The grantee must conduct activities such as kindergarten through 12th-grade health programs, mentoring, internship programs, community partnerships, and leadership training. Reports evaluating these activities must be submitted annually. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2015 through 2020. SEC. 5. ELIMINATING DISPARITIES IN MATERNITY HEALTH OUTCOMES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various healthcare organizations, will conduct research and expand access to services to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. Expand access to services proven to improve maternity care for vulnerable populations and establish a demonstration project in 8 states to compare interventions and reduce disparities in outcomes. States will be selected based on specified regions and populations, ensuring representation of affected communities and testing various models. The Secretary will establish criteria for testing different models in a demonstration project for maternity care interventions with an evidence base. The project will involve consultation with local provider organizations and run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. Grants may be provided for data collection, and participating states must submit reports. The State participating in the demonstration project must report data to the Secretary on project outcomes, costs, and quality of maternity care. A final report on the project results must be submitted to Congress by December 31, 2020. The Health Disparities Education Program is outlined in Section 6. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about racial and ethnic disparities in health care. This program will disseminate scientific evidence and implement outreach campaigns to reduce these disparities. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program to address disparities related to race, ethnicity, age, disability status, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation. This program aims to disseminate research findings, raise awareness about linguistic and cultural barriers in healthcare, and ensure access to language services for individuals with limited-English proficiency. The program aims to provide language access services, disseminate information on various disparities, educate healthcare providers, and assess the impact of the initiatives. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020.
